title: Heavy
data:
***Version [0.30](/0.30 "0.30")**: This article **may not be** up to date for the [latest stable release](/0.32 "0.32") of Crawl.*

|   |                                                                         |
| - | ----------------------------------------------------------------------- |
|   | It deals dramatically more damage, but attacks with it are much slower. |

The **heavy** [brand](/Brand "Brand") does the following:

- Adds +80% base damage, but take 50% longer to swing.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) This results in an average of +20% physical damage.

  - The penalty to [attack speed](/Attack_speed "Attack speed") is applied after skill, but before the effects of [shield](/Shield "Shield") and [armour encumbrance](/Armour_encumbrance "Armour encumbrance").
  - Both base damage and delay are rounded in a weighted manner. For example, a weapon with 16.2 base damage would have a 20% chance to act as 17 base damage, and an 80% chance to act as 16 base damage.

Compared to brands like [flaming](/Flaming "Flaming") and [freezing](/Freezing "Freezing"), heavy weapons are reduced less by [AC](/AC "AC"), but receive less benefit from [slaying](/Slaying "Slaying") and will activate less [auxiliary attacks](/Auxiliary_attack "Auxiliary attack").

## Contents

- [1 Strategy](#Strategy)
  - [1.1 Risks of >1.0 attack delay](#Risks_of_.3E1.0_attack_delay)
- [2 Tips & Tricks](#Tips_.26_Tricks)
- [3 History](#History)
- [4 References](#References)

## Strategy

Heavy offers a slightly weaker damage boost than [flaming](/Flaming "Flaming") or [freezing](/Freezing "Freezing"), but has the benefit of being irresistible. In an average situation, heavy is competitive with those brands. It has a clear superiority against high AC. Conversely, it is clearly worse for [slaying](/Slaying "Slaying")-reliant weapons, like [quick blades](/Quick_blade "Quick blade"). Heavy is also poor for species with strong aux attacks, such as [Tengu](/Tengu "Tengu") or [Vine Stalker](/Vine_Stalker "Vine Stalker").

In addition, heavy weapons are less impacted by shield/armour encumbrance. For example, lets say armour increases attack delay by +0.1 decaAut:

- A regular weapon would go from 1.0 -> 1.1 delay, or 10% slower.
- A heavy weapon would go from 1.5 -> 1.6 delay, or 6.25% slower.

However, using heavy on most weapons introduces a serious risk - see below for details.

### Risks of >1.0 attack delay

Heavy can be a good brand on average, but it can be *very* risky, as it can prevent you from reaching ≤ 1.0 attack delay. Most weapons have a [minimum delay](/Minimum_delay "Minimum delay") of 0.7; heavy turns that into a 1.05 [decaAut](/DecaAut "DecaAut") delay. This represents a 5% chance of a regular speed enemy getting a double-turn of attacks.

For example, a [deep elf annihilator](/Deep_elf_annihilator "Deep elf annihilator")'s crystal spear can deal up to 102 damage. Doubled, that's 204 damage - more than the max HP of many characters. The chance of this actually happening is miniscule (0.003% to maxroll one spear, 5% to double-turn, further reduced by [AC](/AC "AC")/[EV](/EV "EV")/[SH](/SH "SH")...). But it can still be an issue:

- Maximum damage isn't necessary. A high roll, say 80\*2 damage, still really hurts.
- Most dangerous situations in *Crawl* involve multiple enemies. Add a single other [deep elf](/List_of_deep_elves "List of deep elves") to the picture, and max damage increases further. When you consider a pack of enemies, it skyrockets.
- Because "damage you can possibly take in one turn" is doubled, it can force you to use consumables much earlier. For example, a [komodo dragon](/Komodo_dragon "Komodo dragon") deals 34\*2 damage before [GDR](/GDR "GDR"). Therefore, making a melee attack becomes dangerous at \~60 HP rather than \~30 HP. (Remember that [wands](/Wand "Wand"), [Throwing](/Throwing "Throwing"), etc. aren't slowed by your weapon.)

This isn't exclusive to deep elf annihilators - it applies to just about any 10-speed enemy. Suddenly, fighting two [naga sharpshooters](/Naga_sharpshooter "Naga sharpshooter") becomes a big issue; each sharpshooter can do 45 damage before [GDR](/GDR "GDR"), which turns to 150+ damage if the stars align.

Weapons that have a minimum delay below 0.7, like [demon blades](/Demon_blade "Demon blade"), [demon tridents](/Demon_trident "Demon trident"), and all [Short Blades](/Short_Blades "Short Blades"), can reach a post-heavy mindelay below 1.0. Though watch out for [shields](/Shield "Shield"), which can bring the delay back up. Also, for weapons that don't reach 1.0 delay (e.g. [hand crossbow](/Hand_crossbow "Hand crossbow") + any [shield](/Shield "Shield")), this point is obviously moot.

## Tips & Tricks

- Slow actions can be useful in a turn count [speedrun](/Speedrun "Speedrun"). Each attack takes 1 [turn](/Turn "Turn"), regardless of how long the swing was. If a regular weapon would take 3 turns to kill an enemy, a heavy weapon would take 2.

* In addition, swinging an untrained heavy weapon is a better way to skip time than [bread swinging](/Bread_swinging "Bread swinging"). For example, swinging a [scroll](/Scroll "Scroll") takes 1.5 [decaAuts](/DecaAut "DecaAut"), but it takes 2.1 decaAuts to swing a heavy [flail](/Flail "Flail") when you have 0 [Maces & Flails](/Maces_%26_Flails "Maces & Flails") skill.

## History

- In [0.30](/0.30 "0.30"), this weapon brand was introduced. It replaced the [vorpal](/Vorpal "Vorpal") brand.
